question: Which of the following are properties of algorithms? (Select all that apply)
correct: They have a finite number of steps
They produce a definite output for a given input
They can be represented in multiple ways
incorrect: They must always terminate in constant time
They can only solve mathematical problems
hint: Think about the fundamental characteristics that define what an algorithm is, regardless of how it's implemented.

question: Which of these are examples of algorithms in everyday life? (Select all that apply)
correct: A recipe for baking cookies
Directions to drive from one location to another
incorrect: A list of ingredients with no preparation steps
A collection of website bookmarks
A picture showing the finished product
hint: Algorithms are step-by-step procedures for accomplishing tasks with specific inputs and outputs.

question: Which of the following were significant milestones in computing history? (Select all that apply)
correct: The invention of the transistor in 1947
The creation of ENIAC in 1945
The development of the first microprocessor (Intel 4004) in 1971
The introduction of the World Wide Web in 1989
incorrect: The creation of the first personal computer (Altair 8800) in 1975
hint: Consider inventions and developments that fundamentally changed how computers were built or used.

question: Which statements about the decimal number system are true? (Select all that apply)
correct: It uses 10 distinct digits (0-9)
It is a base-10 number system
It is the most commonly used number system by humans in daily life
incorrect: It is primarily used in scientific notation calculations
It consistently requires fewer digits than hexadecimal for the same values
hint: Think about the basic properties of the number system we use every day.

question: Which properties accurately describe the binary number system? (Select all that apply)
correct: It uses only two digits: 0 and 1
It is a base-2 number system
It is fundamental to digital computing
Each binary digit represents a bit
incorrect: Each binary digit represents a byte in computer memory
hint: Consider how binary numbers are represented and why they're important in computing.

question: Which statements about the hexadecimal number system are true? (Select all that apply)
correct: It uses 16 distinct symbols (0-9 and A-F)
It is a base-16 number system
incorrect: It is used primarily for graphics programming
It requires specialized converters to be understood by computers
It was developed specifically for web development
hint: Think about what makes hexadecimal useful and how it relates to other number systems.

question: Which of the following correctly describe units of information in computing? (Select all that apply)
correct: A byte typically consists of 8 bits
A kilobyte (KB) is approximately 1,000 bytes
A gigabyte (GB) is approximately 1 billion bytes
incorrect: A kilobyte (KB) is exactly 1024 bytes in all computing contexts
A bit can store up to 10 different values
hint: Consider the standard definitions of these units and how they relate to each other.

question: Which statements about transistors are accurate? (Select all that apply)
correct: They can function as electronic switches
They are fundamental components in modern processors
They can amplify electronic signals
They replaced vacuum tubes in computers
incorrect: They use heated cathodes to emit electrons like vacuum tubes
They are always larger than integrated circuits
hint: Think about the roles and importance of transistors in electronic devices.

question: Which aspects of Moore's Law are correct? (Select all that apply)
correct: It observed that the number of transistors on integrated circuits doubles approximately every two years
It has been a reliable predictor of computing power growth for several decades
incorrect: It is a mathematical equation that precisely predicts future processor speeds
It states that computer prices will be cut in half every 18 months
It was first observed in the 2000s
hint: Consider what Moore's Law actually predicted and its historical impact on the computing industry.

question: Which statements about Boolean logic are true? (Select all that apply)
correct: It works with only two values: true and false
It forms the foundation of digital circuit design
It was developed by George Boole in the 19th century
incorrect: It can handle more than two values simultaneously
It requires analog circuits to function properly
hint: Think about the fundamental properties of Boolean logic and its applications.

question: Which of the following are basic logic gates? (Select all that apply)
correct: AND gate
OR gate
NOT gate
XOR gate
incorrect: RESET gate
PASS gate
hint: Consider the fundamental building blocks used in digital circuit design.

question: Which statements about basic electronic circuits are true? (Select all that apply)
correct: They can be built using combinations of logic gates
They form the physical implementation of Boolean operations
They can perform arithmetic operations
incorrect: They require alternating current to function
They cannot be connected in series
hint: Think about how circuits function and what they can accomplish in computing.

question: Which of the following are characteristics of a CPU? (Select all that apply)
correct: It executes instructions from programs
It contains an arithmetic logic unit (ALU)
It communicates with memory to retrieve and store data
incorrect: It handles all graphics processing independently
It determines which programs should run on which cores
hint: Consider the core functions and components of the central processing unit.

question: Which statements about memory hierarchy are accurate? (Select all that apply)
correct: Memory closer to the CPU tends to be faster but smaller
Cache memory is faster than main memory
Hard drives provide more storage than RAM but with slower access times
The hierarchy exists to balance speed, cost, and capacity
incorrect: Memory at each level uses identical access speeds
The hierarchy primarily exists to maximize battery life
hint: Think about how different types of memory relate to each other in terms of speed, size, and purpose.

question: Which of the following correctly describe registers in a CPU? (Select all that apply)
correct: They are the fastest memory in a computer
They hold data that the CPU is actively working with
They are typically measured in bits (like 32-bit or 64-bit)
incorrect: They store the operating system
They maintain data when the computer is powered off
hint: Consider the purpose and characteristics of registers within the CPU.

question: Which statements about cache memory are correct? (Select all that apply)
correct: It is faster than main memory (RAM)
It temporarily stores frequently used data
Modern CPUs often have multiple levels of cache (L1, L2, L3)
incorrect: It directly connects to the internet for faster data retrieval
It is primarily used to store the operating system permanently
hint: Think about the purpose of cache memory and how it relates to other memory types.

question: Which of the following correctly describe main memory (RAM)? (Select all that apply)
correct: It provides temporary storage for running programs
It is volatile, meaning it loses data when power is cut
It is typically measured in gigabytes in modern computers
It is faster to access than storage devices like SSDs
incorrect: It provides permanent storage for the BIOS settings
It is mainly used to store video data for graphics processing
hint: Consider the characteristics and role of RAM in a computer system.

question: Which statements about Solid State Drives (SSDs) are true? (Select all that apply)
correct: They have no moving mechanical parts
They are generally faster than traditional hard disk drives
incorrect: They typically consume more power than hard disk drives
They can only store data that is actively being used
They were first introduced in the 2010s
hint: Think about how SSDs differ from other storage technologies.

question: Which of the following accurately describe hard disk drives? (Select all that apply)
correct: They use magnetic platters to store data
They contain mechanical moving parts
They are non-volatile storage devices
They typically offer more storage per dollar than SSDs
incorrect: They access data using laser technology like optical drives
hint: Consider the physical characteristics and performance aspects of traditional hard drives.

question: Which statements correctly describe the 'fetch' stage in the CPU execution cycle? (Select all that apply)
correct: It retrieves the next instruction from memory
It places the instruction in a register
It uses the program counter to determine which instruction to fetch
incorrect: It calculates the results of the instruction
It updates the contents of RAM
hint: Think about what happens in the very first stage of the CPU execution cycle.

question: Which of the following accurately describe the 'decode' stage in the CPU execution cycle? (Select all that apply)
correct: It determines what operation needs to be performed
It identifies what data or operands are needed
incorrect: It retrieves data from long-term storage
It manages the system clock timing
It communicates with peripheral devices
hint: Consider what happens after an instruction is fetched but before it is executed.

question: Which statements about the 'execute' stage in the CPU execution cycle are true? (Select all that apply)
correct: It performs the actual operation specified by the instruction
It may involve the Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU)
It might access memory to read or write data
It can update the status flags in the processor
incorrect: It can only handle numerical operations
hint: Think about what happens when the CPU actually carries out an instruction.

question: Which characteristics correctly describe the Von Neumann Architecture? (Select all that apply)
correct: It stores both data and programs in the same memory
It processes instructions sequentially (unless otherwise directed)
It includes a control unit, ALU, memory, and I/O mechanisms
incorrect: It uses separate physical memory spaces for instructions and data
It was primarily designed for parallel computing
hint: Consider the fundamental design principles of this influential computer architecture.

question: Which of the following are examples of input devices? (Select all that apply)
correct: Keyboard
Mouse
Microphone
Scanner
incorrect: Scanner
hint: Think about devices that allow users to send information to a computer.

question: Which of the following are examples of output devices? (Select all that apply)
correct: Monitor
Printer
Speakers
incorrect: Scanner
Touchpad
hint: Consider devices that present information from a computer to users.

question: Which storage technologies were significant in the history of computer storage? (Select all that apply)
correct: Punched cards
Magnetic tape
Floppy disks
Optical discs (CD, DVD)
incorrect: Solid state memory cards
hint: Think about various storage media used throughout computing history.

question: Which statements correctly compare machine code, assembly code, and high-level programming languages? (Select all that apply)
correct: Machine code consists of binary instructions executed directly by the CPU
Assembly language uses human-readable mnemonics that map closely to machine instructions
High-level languages are more abstracted from hardware details than assembly language
incorrect: Machine code is human-readable text that can be directly edited
High-level languages execute without any translation process
hint: Consider the levels of abstraction and how each type of code relates to the computer hardware.

question: Which of the following correctly describe a computer motherboard and its bus system? (Select all that apply)
correct: The motherboard is the main circuit board that connects all components
Buses are communication pathways that transfer data between components
Different types of buses may operate at different speeds
incorrect: All data on the motherboard travels through the CPU first
The motherboard primarily manages the computer's file system
hint: Think about how components in a computer are physically connected and communicate.

question: Which functions are typically performed by an operating system? (Select all that apply)
correct: Managing hardware resources
Providing a user interface
Handling file storage and organization
Running and scheduling programs
incorrect: Creating physical hardware upgrades for the system
Monitoring the temperature of hardware components
hint: Consider the role of the operating system as an intermediary between hardware and applications.

question: Which characteristics are typical of mobile computing devices? (Select all that apply)
correct: They run on battery power
They prioritize energy efficiency
They typically use touch interfaces
incorrect: They typically have more powerful processors than desktop computers
They cannot function without a constant internet connection
hint: Think about the design priorities and constraints of devices meant to be used on the go.

question: Which statements about desktop computing are true? (Select all that apply)
correct: Desktop computers typically offer more expansion options than laptops
They usually have access to constant power sources
They can often be upgraded with new components over time
They generally offer better performance per dollar than mobile devices
incorrect: They have the same processing capabilities as modern smartphones
hint: Consider the advantages and characteristics of traditional desktop computer systems.

question: Which of the following are characteristics of Internet of Things (IoT) devices? (Select all that apply)
correct: They connect everyday objects to the internet
They often collect and share data about their environment or usage
They frequently have limited computing resources
incorrect: They always require more power than desktop computers
They must be programmed using specialized IoT programming languages
hint: Think about the defining features of devices designed to be part of the Internet of Things ecosystem.

question: Which statements accurately describe computer servers? (Select all that apply)
correct: They are designed to provide services or resources to other computers
They often run continuously with minimal downtime
They may be optimized for reliability and processing power rather than user interface
They can be physically located in dedicated data centers
incorrect: They require specialized cooling systems that regular computers don't need
hint: Consider the purpose and typical characteristics of servers in computing environments.
